history.content: I'm a little confused what you're asking. Are you asking about going to grad school and working at the same time? Or about possibly accepting an offer, and then changing your mind if you're admitted to grad school?

children.subject:
I think a useful heuristic for situations like these is to remember: your actions have consequences, always.

Your primary concern seems to be covering your bases for your post-graduation plans. This is a smart plan to have, in some form or another. However, the strategy of hedging your bets by applying for full-time positions as a back-up to your ideal outcome of grad school does have risks associated with it. You initially mentioned not wanting to break ties with any companies. Well, if you do this then you are potentially doing that. Think of it from the recruiter's perspective: you'll have contact with them and if the process gets to the point where you are given an offer, which you accept as a back-up while you wait, only for you to renege when your grad school applications come back then they will have to explain to their boss why the recruitment process needs to start over again. Has this happened before? If it hasn't, I will willingly eat my clothes. The company probably has a procedure for dealing with it. Does it mean it is consequence free? No. There is a possibility (I would think more likely than not) that recruiter will not have nice things to say about you. Companies consist of people, and people work just like your friends would: how would your friends react to being burned by someone they stuck their neck out for? This leads me to another thing that I think is important if you choose to hedge your bets: be honest with people. If they're asking for dedication, and you know you can't offer that in full honestly, then don't try to convince them that you're dedicated.

I'm not going to comment on possible legal ramification as I'm not qualified to do so, but I can definitely imagine some (albeit incredibly contrived) scenarios in which a company ends up knocking on your door due to a series of terrible decisions. Don't make terrible decisions. What is a terrible decision? The ones that aren't good.

To be clear, there's a difference between reneging on an offer, and simply applying. Just like you can apply to multiple companies at once without the intent on working for all of them simultaneously or even the desire to work at some of them, you can apply to companies without it being binding that you work for them if you get an offer.
In that case, Steven, is it necessary to tell them upfront that I will also be applying to grad school?

If you want? I don't see a reason to. (I never did, mostly out of being lazy than for any actual reasons.)

If (when) they ask you if you're waiting to hear back from any other companies, you can tell them about your grad school plans, or not. Or maybe they'll ask you about whether you intend to accept an offer if you're given one, which is probably not something you would want to say "yes" to anyway, just out of standard practice.

It's probably more sensible to include the information, since it might help you negotiate the offer / deadlines (since grad school results might not have come out yet; this is the most-likely-to-be-problematic point, in that companies might not be willing to wait that long). Or maybe you won't bother.

But there's no real difference between also applying to grad school and also applying to other companies.

Nothing is legally problematic unless you plan on signing an offer and then reneging. Nothing is morally problematic unless you plan on lying to the recruiter and why would you lie about this anyway?

Sorry. To clarify my situation: I fully intend on applying / going to grad school but I would like to pursue a full time position as a backup (in case I change my mind, my acceptances are not what I want, etc.).  

If I wish to go with this, are there any potentially sticky situations I should be aware of?

history.content: My friend working full-time for a tech company and studying full-time as a graduate at the same time, but I'm not sure if it's legal.

If I'm thinking of applying to grad school, would it be okay to apply to full-time positions in industry as well?

Aside from the extra time / effort argument, are there any moral / legal arguments to be made?

Just want to make sure I don't break any ties with companies on accident.
history.subject: Recruiting While Applying to Grad School
